questions.text: A 34-year-old woman complains of sore throat and right-sided ear pain. On examination, her right tonsil appears inflamed and enlarged. Otoscopy reveals no abnormalities. Which nerve is most likely responsible for the referred ear pain?
questions.solution:
• Referred ear pain (otalgia) from tonsillitis is most often due to irritation of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX).
  • This nerve provides sensory innervation to the tonsils and posterior third of the tongue. Also, it contributes to the tympanic plexus via Jacobson's nerve, creating a shared pathway for sensory signals.
  • Inflammation of the tonsils can stimulate this nerve, leading to pain perceived in the ear, despite the ear itself being unaffected.

Referred Otalgia:

  • Ear pain that originates from non-ear structures due to shared sensory innervation.
  • Mechanism: Pain signals from structures outside the ear are transmitted via cranial or cervical nerves that also innervate the external or middle ear.
  • Common Sites, Nerves Involved, and Mechanisms:


Explanation of other options:

Facial nerve (Option B): Mainly controls muscles of facial expression and taste to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It does not transmit sensory input from the tonsillar area.

Trigeminal nerve (Option C): Provides sensation to the face and anterior oral cavity. While it can be involved in referred otalgia (e.g., from dental or sinus problems), it does not mediate pain from the tonsils.

Vagus nerve (Option D): Involved in referred otalgia from laryngeal and hypopharyngeal issues via Arnold's nerve, but it is not the primary nerve for pain arising from the tonsillar region.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with right-sided ear pain, high-grade fever, difficulty in swallowing, and inability to fully open his mouth. On examination, there is trismus. No swelling, redness, or abnormalities are noted on external inspection of the face or oral cavity. There is no visible tonsillar enlargement due to limited mouth opening. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The child's presentation of fever, trismus, odynophagia, and referred ear pain without external findings is most consistent with the diagnosis of Quinsy (peritonsillar abscess).

Quinsy (Peritonsillar Abscess):

  • A complication of acute tonsillitis involves pus collection between the tonsillar capsule and surrounding pharyngeal muscles.
  • Typical Cause: Usually follows an untreated or partially treated episode of acute bacterial tonsillitis.
  • Clinical Features:
    • High-grade fever
    • Sore throat and odynophagia (painful swallowing)
    • Referred ear pain due to shared glossopharyngeal nerve supply
    • Trismus (restricted mouth opening) from involvement of pterygoid muscles
  • Examination Findings:
    • May not show significant external facial or oral abnormalities in early stages
    • As it progresses, tonsillar bulge, uvular deviation, or muffled voice may appear

  • Diagnosis: Primarily clinical; imaging (like ultrasound or CT) may be used if uncertain.
  • Management:
    • Incision and drainage or needle aspiration
    • Antibiotics and supportive care

Explanation of other options:

Pharyngitis (Option A): Usually presents with throat redness and discomfort, but does not typically cause trismus or ear pain.

Parotid abscess (Option B): Presents with parotid swelling and tenderness near the jaw angle; such findings are absent here.

Bezold's Abscess (Option C): A deep neck infection linked to mastoiditis; would present with neck swelling and posterior auricular signs, which are not described.

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal blockage, a diminished sense of smell, and persistent foul-smelling nasal discharge. On anterior rhinoscopy, yellow-green crusts are visible within the nasal cavity. She reports being unaware of the smell herself. Which of the following findings is most likely to be observed on further examination?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of foul-smelling nasal discharge, anosmia, and thick nasal crusts with no awareness of the odor is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis. The most likely finding on further examination is a roomy nasal cavity due to mucosal and turbinate atrophy.

Atrophic Rhinitis:

  • A chronic nasal disorder marked by progressive atrophy of the mucosa, submucosa, and turbinates.
  • Results in the accumulation of thick, foul-smelling crusts within the nasal cavity.
  • Associated with anosmia, so patients are often unaware of the odor (merciful anosmia).
  • Roomy nasal cavity due to atrophy of the nasal turbinates and supporting structures.

Explanation of other options:

Nasal polyps (Option B) present as soft, pale, edematous outgrowths usually in patients with allergic rhinitis or chronic sinusitis. They do not form crusts or produce a foul odor, and anosmia is due to obstruction, not mucosal atrophy.

Inferior turbinate hypertrophy (Option C) is seen in chronic rhinitis or allergic rhinitis and causes nasal congestion, not a roomy cavity. The turbinates are enlarged, not atrophied, and crusting with bad odor is not typical.

Foreign body (Option D): Nasal foreign bodies are more common in children and usually result in unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge. They do not lead to generalized atrophy or bilateral crusting, and anosmia is not a characteristic feature.

questions.text: A young male professional wind instrument player presents with a painless swelling on the left side of his neck. On examination, the swelling produces a gurgling sound on compression. A CT scan is performed. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features and imaging?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of pressure-related neck swelling with a gurgling sound, accompanied by CT evidence of an air-filled lesion adjacent to the larynx, is characteristic of a laryngocele. It is commonly seen in individuals with frequent increases in intralaryngeal pressure, such as trumpet players.

Laryngocele:

  • A laryngocele is an air-filled outpouching of the laryngeal saccule that may communicate with the laryngeal lumen.
  • Etiology: Often develops due to repeated increases in intrathoracic or intra-abdominal pressure, commonly seen in wind instrument players (e.g., trumpet players) or individuals with chronic coughing.
  • Types:
    • Internal laryngocele: Remains within the larynx, may present with hoarseness or airway symptoms.
    • External laryngocele: Extends through the thyrohyoid membrane into the neck, presenting as a compressible neck mass.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Painless, compressible neck swelling that may gurgle on compression
    • Hoarseness or voice changes occur if the internal component compresses the vocal cords
    • Swelling increases with coughing, straining, or blowing
  • Diagnosis:
    • CT scan is the imaging modality of choice, showing an air-filled lesion adjacent to the larynx

Explanation of other options:

Zenker's diverticulum (Option A): A posterior pharyngeal pouch at the cricopharyngeal level, presenting with dysphagia, regurgitation, and aspiration, not a gurgling neck mass.

Tracheoesophageal fistula (Option C): Rare in adults, often due to malignancy or trauma, causing coughing or aspiration during swallowing, not a compressible air-filled neck mass.

Tonsillar mass (Option D): Confined to the oropharynx, causing throat pain or dysphagia, not an air-filled neck swelling.

choices.text: Ligation of the external carotid artery
Ligation of the internal carotid artery

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department with active epistaxis. Conservative measures such as pinching the nose and nasal packing have failed to control the bleeding. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Persistent nasal bleeding despite first-line interventions typically indicates posterior epistaxis, most often originating from the sphenopalatine artery, the main terminal branch supplying the posterior nasal cavity. When conservative options like nasal compression and packing are unsuccessful, endoscopic ligation or cauterization of the sphenopalatine artery is considered the next best step due to its high success rate and relatively low morbidity.

Stepwise Management Approach of Epistaxis:

  • First-line (Initial) Measures:
    • Apply firm pressure by pinching the soft part of the nostrils (initial conservative step)
    • Use anterior or posterior nasal packing if bleeding continues
  • When Nasal Packing Fails:
    • Proceed to endoscopic cauterization or ligation of the sphenopalatine artery (most commonly involved)
  • If Bleeding Still Persists:
    • Ligation of the external carotid artery may be required as a final step in refractory cases

Explanation of other options:

Ligation of the external carotid artery (Option A) is rarely performed today, as endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation or arterial embolization are highly effective and less invasive.

Ligation of the internal carotid artery (Option B): This procedure is rarely done due to the significant risk of cerebrovascular complications, including stroke. It is not part of routine epistaxis management.

Ligation of the maxillary artery (Option D): Although the sphenopalatine artery is a branch of the maxillary artery, directly targeting the sphenopalatine artery via endoscopic access is more effective and precise.

questions.text: A patient with a long-standing history of chronic ear infection presents with high-grade fever, persistent headache, vomiting, irritability, and altered mental status. The CT scan of the brain is provided below. Based on the clinical presentation and imaging findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion in a patient with a chronic ear infection, along with a CT scan revealing a well-defined ring-enhancing lesion in the temporal lobe, suggest a diagnosis of temporal lobe abscess.

Temporal Lobe Abscess:

  • Clinical Features:
    • Nominal Aphasia
    • Homonymous Hemianopia
    • Contralateral Motor Paralysis
    • Epileptic Fits
    • Pupillary Changes/Oculomotor Palsy
  • Investigations:
    1. CT Scan:
      • Ring-enhancing lesion
      • Identifies site, size, and complications (e.g., extradural abscess, sigmoid sinus thrombosis).
    2. MRI: More detailed, improves diagnostic accuracy.
    3. X-ray Mastoid/CT Temporal Bone: To assess ear involvement.
    4. Lumbar Puncture:
      • Done with extreme caution (risk of herniation).
      • Findings: ↑ pressure, ↑ protein, normal glucose, mild ↑ WBC (polymorphs/lymphocytes).
  • Treatment:
    • Medical Management:
      • Antibiotics (IV, often combined due to mixed flora):
        • Chloramphenicol, 3rd-gen cephalosporins
      • ICP Management:
        • Dexamethasone 4mg IV 6-hourly
        • Mannitol 20%, 0.5g/kg
      • Ear discharge care: Suction + topical antibiotics
    • Neurosurgical Options:
      • Aspiration via burr hole
      • Open incision and drainage
      • Complete excision (if abscess enlarges or persists)

Explanation of other options:

Cerebellar abscess (Option B): This may occur from middle ear infections but typically presents with ataxia, imbalance, dysmetria, or nystagmus, none of which are described here.

Subdural abscess (Option C): Also called subdural empyema, this condition appears as a crescent-shaped collection between the dura and arachnoid mater, not as a focal ring lesion in the brain parenchyma.

Meningitis (Option D): Leads to diffuse meningeal enhancement on imaging, often with no discrete ring-enhancing lesion. Clinical signs include neck stiffness and photophobia, which are not mentioned.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male reports persistent right-sided nasal blockage and recurrent nosebleeds for the past year. Nasal endoscopy reveals a reddish mass, and contrast-enhanced CT imaging shows a lesion originating in the posterior nasal cavity, extending into the nasopharynx. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of progressive unilateral nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis in an adolescent male, along with imaging showing a nasopharyngeal mass, point toward juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA):

  • Origin: Arises from the posterolateral wall of the nasal cavity and extends into the nasopharynx.
  • Demographics: Primarily affects adolescent males (ages 10-20); very rare in females or older individuals.
  • Nature: Benign but highly vascular tumor; manipulation can cause severe bleeding.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Nasal & Nasopharyngeal Symptoms:
      • Epistaxis: Recurrent, spontaneous nosebleeds due to fragile blood vessels.
      • Nasal Obstruction: Gradually worsening blockage; may result in a nasal-sounding voice.
      • Nasal Discharge: Often secondary to sinus blockage or infection.
    • Ear Symptoms:
      • Conductive Hearing Loss: From Eustachian tube compression.
      • Otitis Media with Effusion: Due to impaired middle ear drainage, it may cause ear pain or fullness.
    • Ophthalmic & Neurological Signs:
      • Proptosis: Forward displacement of the eye from orbital extension.
      • Diplopia: Double vision due to cranial nerve involvement (III, IV, VI).
      • Cranial Nerve Involvement: Can affect CN II (vision), CN V (facial pain), CN IX/X (swallowing difficulty).
    • Facial Deformity:
      • Widening of Nasal Bridge: Pressure effect from tumor mass.
      • Cheek Swelling: Indicates lateral extension.
      • "Frog-Face" Deformity: Bilateral proptosis with midface flattening.

  • Other Findings:
    • Endoscopy: Reveals a smooth or lobulated reddish mass obstructing the nasal passage.
    • Tumor Consistency: Firm; biopsy should be avoided due to the risk of hemorrhage.

Explanation of other options:

Antrochoanal polyp (Option B): Originates from the maxillary sinus and extends toward the choana. Typically presents with nasal obstruction but not recurrent bleeding, and doesn't show the intense vascularity of JNA.

Rhinoscleroma (Option C): A chronic granulomatous infection caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis. Though it may cause nasal blockage, it's more often bilateral, lacks epistaxis, and shows Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies histologically.

Concha bullosa (Option D): This is an anatomical variant involving an air-filled middle turbinate. It does not cause recurrent epistaxis or appear as a mass on imaging extending into the nasopharynx.

questions.text: A patient arrives with a sudden worsening of asthma symptoms. He mentions a past history of chronic sinus headaches and self-treatment for sinusitis. On examination, nasal polyps are identified. Which of the following drugs most likely triggered this episode?
questions.solution:
The patient's asthma exacerbation, combined with nasal polyps and a history of sinus issues, suggests Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD), where NSAIDs like aspirin can trigger bronchospasm.

Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease (AERD)/ Samter's Triad:

  • A chronic inflammatory condition characterized by:
    • Asthma
    • Chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal polyps
    • Sensitivity to aspirin/NSAIDs (COX-1 inhibitors)
  • Typically develops between ages 20-50.
  • Symptoms:
    • Respiratory Triggers:
      • On exposure to NSAIDs: nasal congestion, sinus pressure, sneezing, cough, wheeze, chest tightness.
    • Chronic Features:
      • Persistent nasal congestion
      • Recurrent nasal polyps
      • Asthma
      • Anosmia
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical diagnosis based on the triad: asthma + nasal polyps + NSAID-induced respiratory symptoms.
    • Aspirin challenge test (oral or intranasal) may be used in unclear cases, performed under supervision.
    • Eosinophilia:
      • Increased eosinophils in nasal polyps and sometimes in peripheral blood (supportive but not diagnostic).
  • Management:
    • Avoidance:
      • Strict NSAID avoidance unless desensitized.
      • Acetaminophen is typically safe at doses ≤500 mg.
    • Medical Therapy:
      • Inhaled corticosteroids: for asthma.
      • Intranasal steroids (sprays/rinses): for nasal symptoms.
      • Oral steroids: for severe nasal polyps.

Explanation of other options:

Cotrimoxazole (Option A): Commonly used for bacterial infections. It may cause allergic reactions, but it is not linked with triggering asthma attacks in AERD.

Co-amoxiclav (Option B): A penicillin-class antibiotic. Although hypersensitivity reactions can occur, it is not associated with asthma exacerbation in patients with nasal polyps.

Chloramphenicol (Option D): This antimicrobial agent is not commonly used for sinusitis and is not known to provoke respiratory symptoms in sensitive individuals.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with left-sided nonaxial proptosis. He has a history of a road traffic accident 15 years ago. A CT scan of the head and orbits is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of nonaxial proptosis in a young male with a remote history of trauma and CT findings of a frontal sinus lesion with orbital extension strongly suggests a frontal mucocele.

Frontal Mucocele:

  • A frontal mucocele is a cystic lesion caused by the blockage of sinus drainage, leading to the accumulation of mucus.
  • It often arises due to chronic inflammation, previous surgery, or trauma, especially involving the frontal recess.
  • The expanding lesion can erode surrounding bone and extend into the orbit or intracranial cavity.
  • Common Symptoms:
    • Proptosis (bulging of the eye)
    • Facial pain or headache
    • Visual disturbances such as blurred or double vision
    • Nasal symptoms like congestion or persistent discharge
    • Sinus pressure or fullness sensation
    • Tenderness or swelling over the frontal bone region

Explanation of other options:

Frontal meningioma (Option B): Typically arises from intracranial meninges; while it can cause proptosis, it's less likely in this age group and has no direct link to past trauma.

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Option C): A vascular tumor mostly affecting adolescent males, originating from the nasopharynx, not the frontal sinus, and unrelated to past injury.

Pseudotumor of the orbit (Option D): An idiopathic inflammatory condition of the orbit, often painful and acute, not associated with chronic expansion from sinus pathology or distant trauma.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with hoarseness and progressive dysphagia. He was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma, for which surgical management was performed. The postoperative image provided shows a permanent opening in the anterior neck. Based on the clinical history and image, which of the following surgical procedures was most likely performed?
questions.solution:
The presence of a permanent stoma in the anterior neck, along with the history of laryngeal cancer, suggests that a total laryngectomy was performed. This surgery involves complete removal of the larynx, with the trachea brought out to the skin as a permanent airway.

Total Laryngectomy:

  • Surgical removal of the entire larynx, typically resulting in permanent separation of the airway from the mouth and nose.
  • Indications:
    • Advanced laryngeal cancer (e.g., T4a stage with thyroid cartilage invasion).
    • Stage 3 or 4a tumours in patients unfit for chemoradiation.
    • Recurrent tumours after previous treatments.
    • Bilateral arytenoid involvement affects vocal cord mobility.
  • Procedure:
    • The larynx is completely excised.
    • The trachea is brought out to the anterior neck, forming a permanent stoma.
    • This stoma becomes the new airway, bypassing the upper respiratory tract.

  • Postoperative Considerations:
    • Patients lose their natural voice and require alternative communication methods (e.g., electrolarynx, voice prosthesis).
    • Rehabilitation is essential for speech and swallowing.
  • Common in: Advanced cases not responding to other modalities like radiotherapy or chemotherapy.

Explanation of other options:

Partial laryngectomy (Option A): This preserves part of the larynx and is used in select early-stage cases; patients can still phonate and breathe through the natural airway.

Percutaneous tracheostomy (Option B): Typically done in ICU settings for airway management; it's not curative for laryngeal malignancy.

Standard tracheostomy (Option C): Provides a temporary airway below the larynx but does not involve removal of the larynx or the creation of a permanent stoma for breathing in cancer patients.

questions.text: A female patient undergoing evaluation for hearing loss shows a negative Rinne test at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, while the Rinne test becomes positive at 1024 Hz. Based on these findings, what is the likely difference between air conduction (AC) and bone conduction (BC)?
questions.solution:
A negative Rinne at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, with a positive result at 1024 Hz, typically corresponds to an air-bone gap of 30-45 dB.

Rinne Test:

  • Compares air conduction (AC) to bone conduction (BC) of sound in the same ear.
  • Procedure:
    • A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid process.
    • When the sound is no longer heard, it is moved beside the ear canal (meatus).
    • Patient reports if the sound is still audible (AC > BC = Positive Rinne).
  • Interpretation:
    • Positive Rinne Test (AC > BC)
      • Seen in:
        • Normal hearing
        • Sensorineural hearing loss
    • Negative Rinne Test (BC > AC)
      • Indicates conductive hearing loss
      • Suggests a minimum air-bone gap (ABG) of 15-20 dB

questions.text: A labeled nasoendoscopic image of the nasopharynx shows a specific structure marked by a yellow arrow. Which of the following best identifies this anatomical structure?
questions.solution:
The yellow arrow indicates a lateral recess in the nasopharynx, situated posterior to the eustachian tube opening, known as the Fossa of Rosenmuller.

Fossa of Rosenmuller:

  • The most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Located superior and posterior to the torus tubarius
  • Torus tubarius: Elevation formed by the cartilaginous end of the Eustachian tube

Explanation of other options:

Tubal tonsil (Option B): This is a small collection of lymphoid tissue near the opening of the Eustachian tube, but it does not form a recess like the fossa of Rosenmuller.

Opening of the Eustachian tube (Option C): Appears as a slit-like opening anterior to the fossa and is responsible for equalizing middle ear pressure.

Adenoids (Option D): Refers to lymphoid tissue located in the roof and posterior wall of the nasopharynx, not in the lateral wall where the fossa is found.

Reference: https://radiopaedia.org/articles/fossa-of-rosenmuller-2

choices.text: When the head is turned to the left, the eyes move left with nystagmus
When the head is turned to the left, the eyes move right with nystagmus
When the head is turned to the right, the eyes move right with nystagmus
When the head is turned to the right, the eyes move left with nystagmus

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with an acute onset of vertigo and is diagnosed with right-sided vestibular neuronitis. What would the head impulse test most likely reveal in this patient?
questions.solution:
In right-sided vestibular neuronitis, the right vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) is impaired. So when the head is turned to the right, the eyes move right with a corrective saccade to the left. This indicates a deficient right-sided VOR.

Vestibular Neuronitis:

  • Acute inflammation of the vestibular nerve, often viral in origin.
  • Characterized by the sudden onset of vertigo, nausea, and imbalance.
  • Hearing is typically unaffected (no sensorineural hearing loss).

Head Impulse Test (HIT) / Head Thrust Test:

  • Purpose: Assesses the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) to detect peripheral vestibular dysfunction.
  • Patient Position: Eyes fixed on the examiner's nose throughout the test.
  • Procedure:
    • The examiner holds the patient's head and rapidly rotates it to one side.
    • In a normal VOR, eyes remain fixed on the target (examiner's nose).
    • In vestibular dysfunction, the eyes move with the head, followed by a corrective saccade back to the target.
  • Findings in Right Vestibular Neuronitis:
    • The right VOR is impaired.
    • When the head is turned right, the eyes move right with the head.
    • A corrective saccade to the left follows to regain fixation.
    • Indicates a right-sided vestibular deficit.

Explanation of other options:

When the head is turned to the left, the eyes move left with nystagmus (Option A): This reflects a normal vestibulo-ocular reflex or possible left-sided dysfunction, but it does not correspond to findings in right-sided vestibular neuronitis.

When the head is turned to the left, the eyes move right with nystagmus (Option B): This implies a direction-changing nystagmus, which is more typical of central lesions; vestibular neuronitis typically causes unidirectional nystagmus.

When the head is turned to the right, the eyes move left with nystagmus (Option D): This describes left-beating nystagmus, which may be seen at rest in right-sided vestibular neuronitis, but not during the head impulse test, where a corrective saccade, not nystagmus, is the expected finding.

questions.text: A professional vocalist reports difficulty achieving higher-pitched notes during singing. On laryngoscopic examination, her vocal cords appear bowed and positioned lower than usual. Which of the following muscles is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
A singer struggling to raise her voice's pitch likely has dysfunction of the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for tightening the vocal cords.

Cricothyroid Muscle and Voice Function:

  • Primary Function: Tenses and lengthens the vocal cords to raise the vocal pitch.
  • Voice Modulation: Essential for producing high-pitched sounds, especially in singers.
  • Effect of Dysfunction:
    • Inability to increase vocal pitch effectively.
    • May present as vocal fatigue or weakness when attempting high notes.
  • Clinical Signs:
    • Vocal cords may appear bowed or slackened on laryngoscopic examination.
    • Pitch elevation becomes impaired due to reduced tension on the cords.
  • Common in: Vocal professionals (e.g., singers) presenting with pitch control issues.

Intrinsic Muscles of the Larynx:



Explanation of other options:

Interarytenoid (Option B): Primarily contributes to closing the posterior part of the glottis by bringing the arytenoids together, aiding in phonation, not in pitch control.

Posterior cricoarytenoid (Option C): Acts to abduct (open) the vocal cords during breathing; it does not contribute to pitch modulation.

Lateral arytenoid (Option D): Responsible for adducting (closing) the vocal cords for speech production, but does not influence their tension or pitch.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK545231/

questions.text: During surgery, the surgeon makes the incision shown below. Based on the location and type of incision, which of the following surgeries is being performed?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a trans-columellar incision typically shaped like an inverted "V" or stair-step, used in open rhinoplasty.

Transcolumellar Incision:


  • Surgical Approach: Commonly used in open rhinoplasty procedures.
  • Location: Made at the base of the columella (the tissue between the nostrils).
  • Shape: Typically designed in a stair-step, inverted V, or inverted W pattern to reduce visible scarring.
  • Purpose:
    • Allows lifting of the nasal skin for clear exposure of internal structures.
    • Provides direct access to the nasal tip cartilages and other components.
    • Enables precise reshaping and correction of the nasal framework.
  • Advantage: Offers better visualization and control compared to closed techniques.

Explanation of other options:

Caldwell-Luc procedure (Option B): This procedure involves an incision in the gingivolabial sulcus (above the upper canine tooth) to access the maxillary sinus, not through the columella, making it unrelated to the incision shown.

Septoplasty (Option C): Corrects a deviated nasal septum via internal nasal mucosal incisions, typically done inside the nostril, so it does not require any external skin incision like the one shown.

Sinusotomy (Option D): A sinusotomy is performed to open blocked sinuses, most commonly using an endoscopic or intranasal approach, and does not involve any external incision on the columella.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK546628//
  2. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35791572/

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman reports a slowly progressive hearing loss in her right ear along with pulsatile tinnitus. Otoscopic examination reveals a reddish, pulsatile mass visible behind the tympanic membrane. A CT scan of the temporal bone was obtained and is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of pulsatile tinnitus and a reddish mass behind the tympanic membrane on otoscopy, along with a vascular middle ear lesion on CT, is characteristic of Glomus Tympanicum.

Glomus Tumour:

  • Most common benign middle ear tumour.
  • Arises from glomus bodies (paraganglionic tissue) of neural crest origin.
  • Two types:
    • Glomus Tympanicum - from the promontory.
    • Glomus Jugulare - from the dome of the jugular bulb.
  • Pathology:
    • Middle-aged females (40-50 years), F: M = 5:1.
    • Slow-growing, highly vascular, non-encapsulated.
    • May bleed profusely due to thin-walled vessels.
  • Clinical Features:
    1. Ear symptoms:
      • Conductive hearing loss.
      • Pulsatile tinnitus (stops with carotid pressure).
      • Red reflex behind TM ("rising sun").
      • Brown's sign: Tumour blanches on pressure.
    2. Polyp form:
      • Bleeding, vertigo, and facial palsy.
      • May mimic CSOM with a polyp.
    3. Late cranial nerve palsies (IX-XII):
      • Dysphagia, hoarseness, tongue atrophy.
    4. Audible bruit over mastoid.
  • Diagnosis:
    • CT: Bony erosion, differentiate tympanicum vs jugulare.
    • MRI/MRA: Soft tissue + vascular invasion.
    • Biopsy contraindicated due to bleeding risk.
  • Treatment:
    • Surgery (mainstay): Depends on the tumour size/location.
    • Pre-op embolisation: ↓ bleeding.
    • Radiotherapy: For inoperable/recurrent cases.

Explanation of other options:

Cholesteatoma (Option A): Usually presents with chronic ear discharge and hearing loss, but does not appear as a vascular mass or cause pulsatile tinnitus.

Acoustic Neuroma (Option C): Involves the vestibulocochlear nerve, leading to sensorineural hearing loss and imbalance, not a middle ear mass.

Otosclerosis (Option D): Affects the stapes footplate and causes bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss, but there is no visible mass or pulsatile tinnitus.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK553163/

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with high-grade fever, trismus, painful swallowing, and a firm swelling on the side of the neck just below the angle of the mandible. On examination, the tonsil appears pushed medially with bulging of the lateral pharyngeal wall. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fever, trismus, painful swallowing, and medial displacement of the tonsil with lateral pharyngeal wall bulging points toward a diagnosis of parapharyngeal abscess.

Parapharyngeal Abscess:

  • Common Causes:
    • Pharyngeal infections: Chronic or acute tonsillitis, adenoiditis, or spread from peritonsillar abscess
    • Dental origin: Often related to infections from the lower third molars
    • Ear-related: Infections like Bezold's abscess or petrositis
    • Extension from nearby spaces: Including retropharyngeal, parotid, and submandibular areas
    • External trauma: Penetrating injuries or post-surgical infections
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • General symptoms: Fever, sore throat, painful swallowing (odynophagia), and neck stiffness
    • Torticollis and signs of systemic infection may be present
    • Localized swelling: A firm mass on the neck, possibly pushing the tonsil medially
  • Management:
    • Initial therapy: Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics
    • Definitive treatment: Surgical drainage of the abscess when indicated

Explanation of other options:

Quinsy (Option A): Also known as a peritonsillar abscess, quinsy presents with uvular deviation, trismus, and a "hot potato" voice rather than visible neck swelling. It typically does not cause prominent external neck swelling.

Retropharyngeal abscess (Option C): This usually presents with a posterior pharyngeal wall bulge, neck stiffness, and respiratory distress, particularly in children. It does not typically cause lateral neck swelling or tonsillar displacement.

Tonsillitis (Option D): Presents with sore throat, fever, and enlarged, inflamed tonsils but does not usually cause asymmetrical tonsillar displacement or a palpable neck mass. There is no collection of pus or deep space involvement.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with persistent clear nasal discharge from one side, which began two days after a head injury sustained in a road traffic accident. The discharge increases when he bends forward. There is no associated fever, nasal congestion, or sneezing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of unilateral clear nasal discharge following head trauma, especially worsening on bending forward, are classic for CSF rhinorrhea.

CSF Rhinorrhea:

  • It is the leakage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) through the nose, often secondary to a defect in the skull base.
  • The fluid is typically clear and watery, and may increase with posture changes like bending forward.
  • Common Sites of Leak:
    • Cribriform plate (most frequent location)
    • Roof of the ethmoid sinus
    • Frontal sinus wall
    • Sphenoid sinus (particularly post-trauma)
    • Temporal bone (can lead to CSF reaching middle ear and draining through Eustachian tube - CSF otorhinorrhea)
    • Skull base defects involving the anterior or middle cranial fossa
  • Etiological Classification:
    • Traumatic (most common)
      • Accidental: Road traffic accidents or blunt trauma
      • Iatrogenic: Postoperative leaks after nasal or skull base surgeries (e.g., polypectomy, sinus surgery)
    • Infective/Inflammatory
      • Chronic infections (e.g., fungal sinusitis, osteomyelitis)
      • Expansile lesions like mucoceles
    • Neoplastic
      • Skull base tumors (both benign and malignant) that erode bony structures
    • Congenital
      • Skull base anomalies such as meningocele or meningoencephalocele
      • Nasal gliomas
    • Idiopathic
      • Spontaneous leaks without clear underlying pathology, sometimes linked to raised intracranial pressure
  • Diagnostic Evaluation:
    • Clinical Tests:
      • Handkerchief Test (Halo Sign): CSF forms a double ring when mixed with blood on filter paper
      • Valsalva maneuver may provoke leakage in some cases
    • Biochemical Confirmation:
      • Beta-2 transferrin assay: Highly specific marker for CSF; gold standard for confirming diagnosis
    • Imaging:
      • High-Resolution CT Scan: Best for identifying osseous defects at the skull base
      • CT Cisternography: Useful for active leaks; contrast outlines the path of CSF escape

Explanation of other options:

CSF otorrhea (Option A): This refers to cerebrospinal fluid leaking from the ear, typically due to temporal bone fractures, not the nose. The absence of ear discharge and the presence of nasal leakage rule this out.

Allergic rhinitis (Option C): Usually presents with bilateral watery discharge, sneezing, nasal congestion, and itching, none of which are reported in this case. Also, it is unrelated to head trauma.

Vasomotor rhinitis (Option D): This condition involves non-allergic, chronic nasal discharge triggered by temperature, humidity, or irritants. It does not follow trauma and is typically bilateral, not one-sided.

Reference: Cribriform plate

choices.text: Cessation of smoking and do a biopsy

questions.text: A middle-aged male with a history of chronic tobacco use presents with a white, slightly thickened patch on the ventral surface of his tongue, as shown in the image. The lesion has been present for several weeks, is non-painful, and does not scrape off on examination. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The white lesion described is suggestive of leukoplakia, a potentially pre-cancerous condition linked to chronic irritation, commonly due to tobacco. Smoking cessation is essential to halt progression, and a biopsy is necessary to assess for any underlying dysplasia or malignancy.

Leukoplakia:

  • Defined by WHO as a clinical white patch on oral mucosa that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease.
  • Etiology:
    • Tobacco use: Smoking and chewing.
    • Alcohol abuse, especially when combined with smoking.
    • Chronic trauma: Ill-fitting dentures, cheek bites.
    • Associations: Oral submucous fibrosis, hyperplastic candidiasis, Plummer-Vinson syndrome.
  • Common Sites:
    • Most common: Buccal mucosa, especially in India.
    • Others: Oral commissures, floor of mouth, tongue, gingivobuccal sulcus, lip mucosa.
  • Age & Sex:
    • Common in the 4th decade of life.
    • Male predominance (2-3 times more than females).
  • Malignant Potential: Risk ranges from 1% to 17.5%.
  • Management:
    1. Eliminate causative factors (e.g., stop tobacco use).
    2. Biopsy: Indicated in high-risk lesions to rule out malignancy.
    3. Treatment:
      • Surgical excision (especially for suspicious small lesions).
      • Laser ablation or cryotherapy as alternatives.

Explanation of other options:

Give corticosteroids (Option A): Corticosteroids are used to reduce inflammation in autoimmune or inflammatory oral lesions (e.g., lichen planus), but they are not appropriate for suspected premalignant conditions like leukoplakia.

Lifestyle modification (Option C): While general lifestyle changes (diet, hygiene) support oral health, they are not adequate as standalone measures in a patient with a suspicious white lesion.

Injection of vitamin B12 (Option D): Vitamin B12 is indicated for nutritional deficiencies that cause glossitis or burning mouth syndrome, not for keratotic lesions like leukoplakia. It has no therapeutic role in the evaluation or management of potentially premalignant lesions.

Reference:

Smoker's Palate: An Often Misunderstood Benign Lesion of the Oral Cavity - PMC

Oral Mucosal Lesions Associated with Smokers and Chewers – A Case-Control Study in Chennai Population - PMC

questions.text: A patient recently underwent surgery involving the lateral skull base. In the postoperative period, the patient develops aspiration while speaking ability and vocal tone remain unaffected. Which of the following nerve injuries best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of aspiration without voice change following skull base surgery points toward a diagnosis of superior laryngeal nerve injury.

Superior Laryngeal Nerve (SLN):

  • Origin: Branch of the vagus nerve (CN X).
  • Divisions:
    • External branch (ebSLN) - Motor branch
    • Internal branch (ibSLN) - Sensory branch
  • Functions:
    • External branch of SLN:
      • Supplies the cricothyroid muscle, which tenses the vocal cords to modulate pitch.
    • Internal branch of SLN:
      • Provides sensation above the vocal cords, including the epiglottis and aryepiglottic folds.
      • Essential for initiating the cough reflex and airway protection during swallowing.
  • Clinical Implications of Injury:
    • External branch of SLN injury:
      • May cause difficulty adjusting vocal pitch (especially in singers or voice professionals).
      • Minimal impact on voice in regular speech.
    • Internal branch of SLN injury:
      • Leads to loss of sensation above the vocal cords, impairing the cough reflex.
      • Increases aspiration risk during swallowing.
    • SLN palsy (both branches):
      • Can result in vocal fatigue, reduced pitch control, and subtle voice changes.

Explanation of other options:

Glossopharyngeal nerve injury (Option B): This nerve mainly contributes to pharyngeal sensation and taste from the posterior third of the tongue. Its damage may cause dysphagia, but aspiration without voice changes is less typical.

Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury (Option C): This nerve innervates most of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx. Injury commonly results in vocal cord paralysis, leading to hoarseness or voice changes, which are absent here.

High vagal injury (Option D): A lesion at this level would affect both the recurrent and superior laryngeal branches, resulting in voice changes and possibly aspiration. Since there is no vocal alteration, this is unlikely.

Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8305207/

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with bilateral hearing loss and tinnitus. She reports that her hearing improves in noisy environments. Otoscopic examination reveals intact tympanic membranes bilaterally. The Rinne test is negative on both sides. Pure tone audiometry is performed. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The combination of bilateral conductive hearing loss, intact eardrums, and a positive phenomenon of hearing better in noisy environments is characteristic of stapedial otosclerosis.

Stapedial Otosclerosis:

  • Abnormal bone deposition around the stapes footplate, causing stapes fixation → Conductive hearing loss (CHL).
  • Clinical Findings:
    • Hearing better in noise - Classic feature of CHL.
    • Rinne Test: Negative bilaterally (BC > AC).
    • Weber Test: Lateralizes to the affected ear.
    • Otoscopy: The Tympanic membrane usually appears normal.
  • Diagnostic Tests:
    • Tuning Fork Tests:
      • Rinne: Negative (CHL)
      • Weber: Lateralizes to the affected side
    • Pure Tone Audiometry:
      • Air conduction: Elevated thresholds
      • Bone conduction: Normal or slightly reduced (Carhart notch at 2 kHz)
      • Air-bone gap: >10 dB
    • Tympanometry:
      • Normal middle ear pressure
      • Reduced compliance may be seen
    • Stapedial Reflex:
      • Usually absent in otosclerosis
    • CT Temporal Bone (High Resolution):
      • Shows hypodense focus in active disease
      • Not helpful in inactive disease (sclerotic)

Explanation of other options:

Meniere's disease (Option A): Presents with episodic vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus. Audiometry reveals a low-frequency sensorineural loss, not a conductive pattern.

Endolymphatic fistula (Option B): Often presents after trauma or barotrauma with fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss and vertigo, rather than conductive hearing loss and negative Rinne's.

Vestibular schwannoma (Option D): Usually presents with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and imbalance. Rinne's test is typically positive or sensorineural in pattern, and the condition rarely causes bilateral conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with high-grade fever, right-sided ear pain, and recent-onset conductive hearing loss. He has a history of unresolved acute otitis media. On examination, there is postauricular erythema, swelling, tenderness, and outward displacement of the pinna. Based on the clinical scenario and the image provided, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of erythematous swelling over the mastoid area with recent ear infection is classic for acute mastoiditis, a complication of untreated otitis media.

Acute Mastoiditis:

  • A bacterial infection involving the mastoid air cells typically follows untreated or inadequately managed acute otitis media.
  • Pathophysiology: Infection spreads from the middle ear to the mastoid bone, leading to inflammation and pus formation within the mastoid air cells.
  • Common Clinical Features:
    • Pain and tenderness are localized over the mastoid region
    • Redness and swelling behind the ear (postauricular area)
    • Fever, often with chills
    • Conductive hearing loss due to middle ear fluid accumulation
    • Outward displacement of the pinna (ear protrusion)
  • Complications if Untreated:
    • Intracranial spread (e.g., meningitis)
    • Formation of abscesses
    • Facial nerve involvement or other cranial nerve deficits
  • Management:
    • Initiate intravenous antibiotics promptly
    • In cases with poor response or complications, surgical drainage (mastoidectomy) may be required

Explanation of other options:

Furunculosis (Option A): This is a localized infection of a hair follicle in the external auditory canal and typically appears as a painful nodule inside the ear, not over the mastoid bone.

Fibrous dysplasia (Option C): A non-infectious condition where bone is replaced with fibrous tissue. It is slow-growing, painless, and doesn't present with redness or acute inflammation.

Facial palsy (Option D): Involves dysfunction of the facial nerve and leads to facial weakness or paralysis but does not produce postauricular swelling or redness.

choices.text: All cases should be treated with prophylactic antibiotics
It may result in cauliflower ear
Caused by bleeding into the space beneath the perichondrium
It usually resolves on its own without intervention

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a history of ear trauma. Examination reveals swelling, tenderness, and a bluish discoloration of the external ear, as shown in the image. Based on the clinical findings, which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of ear swelling, tenderness, and discoloration following trauma is characteristic of an auricular hematoma, caused by blood accumulation between the cartilage and perichondrium. This condition does not resolve spontaneously and requires prompt drainage to prevent complications like cauliflower ear.

Auricular Hematoma:

  • Results from trauma to the external ear, causing blood accumulation between the cartilage and perichondrium. (Option C)
  • Prompt intervention is essential, typically involving aspiration or surgical drainage.
  • Prophylactic antibiotics are often administered to reduce the risk of infection, such as chondritis or cellulitis. (Option A)
  • If left untreated, it can cause fibrosis and cartilage necrosis, leading to a permanent ear deformity known as cauliflower ear (also called pugilistic ear), often seen in combat sports. (Option B)
  • Pressure dressing may be applied post-drainage to prevent reaccumulation of blood.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of persistent right-sided nasal obstruction and occasional blood-stained nasal discharge. Contrast-enhanced CT and nasal endoscopy are taken and shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's unilateral nasal obstruction with blood-stained discharge, endoscopy finding of a friable nasal mass, and CT evidence of a lateral nasal wall lesion suggest an inverted papilloma.

Inverted Papilloma:

  • A benign tumor found in the nasal cavity or paranasal sinuses with potential for local invasion and recurrence.
  • Site of Origin:
    • Arises from the Schneiderian membrane (non-olfactory nasal mucosa).
    • Most commonly found on the lateral nasal wall, especially near the middle meatus.
  • Growth Pattern:
    • Exhibits inverted growth, the epithelium proliferates inward into the underlying connective tissue.
  • HPV Association:
    • Frequently linked with HPV types 6 and 11.
  • Risk of Malignancy:
    • Around 10-15% of cases may transform into squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Common Symptoms:
    • Unilateral nasal blockage
    • Recurrent epistaxis (nosebleeds)
    • May also cause chronic sinus infections.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Requires nasal endoscopy and biopsy to confirm histological features.
  • Treatment Approach:
    • Managed by complete endoscopic surgical excision.
    • Aim is to prevent recurrence and reduce the risk of malignant transformation.

Explanation of other options:

Carcinoma maxilla (Option B): Usually presents with cheek swelling, facial pain, and loosening of teeth. More likely to cause bony destruction rather than remodeling seen in inverted papilloma.

Esthesioneuroblastoma (Option C): Arises from the olfactory epithelium in the upper nasal vault and typically presents with anosmia and more extensive craniofacial involvement on imaging.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Option D): Occurs almost exclusively in adolescent males and presents with profuse epistaxis. It originates from the posterior nasal cavity, not the lateral nasal wall.

questions.text: On the CT image of the paranasal sinuses, identify the best description of the structure marked in the scan.
questions.solution:
The CT scan shows an air-filled cavity within the superior nasal turbinate, indicating a pneumatized superior turbinate, a rare anatomical variant.

Pneumatized Superior Turbinate (Superior Concha Bullosa):

  • Refers to the presence of an air-filled cavity within the superior nasal turbinate.
  • Prevalence:
    • Considered a rare anatomical variant compared to middle concha bullosa.
  • Symptoms (if present):
    • Often asymptomatic and detected incidentally on imaging.
    • When symptomatic, may present with:
      • Nasal obstruction or blockage
      • Headache
      • Chronic or recurrent sinusitis
      • Olfactory disturbances
  • Diagnosis:
    • High-resolution CT scan of the paranasal sinuses is the best imaging modality.
    • Helps differentiate from adjacent sinus pathology.

Explanation of other options:

Agger nasi cell (Option A): Located anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate and above the lacrimal bone, this is the most anterior ethmoidal air cell and plays a role in the drainage of the frontal sinus.

Onodi cell (Option C): This is a posterior ethmoid air cell that may pneumatize close to or around the optic nerve and sphenoid sinus, posing surgical risks.

Haller cell (Option D): These are infraorbital ethmoid air cells extending into the floor of the orbit, potentially narrowing the infundibulum and frontal recess.

Reference:

Role of Superior Turbinate Pneumatisation in Chronic Rhinosinusitis - PMC

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of vertigo, a sensation of ear fullness, and tinnitus. He notes that his symptoms lessen when he lies with his right ear facing upward. He has a history of right ear surgery performed six months ago for a safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's vertigo, tinnitus, and fullness in the ear following recent middle ear surgery, with symptom relief on positional change, point toward a perilymphatic fistula.

Perilymphatic Fistula (PLF):

  • An abnormal connection between the middle ear and the inner ear's perilymphatic space, typically involving the oval or round window.
  • Causes:
    • Trauma to the head
    • Barotrauma (e.g., during diving or air travel)
    • Previous ear surgeries, especially stapedectomy
    • Congenital temporal bone defects
  • Clinical Features:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss that may fluctuate
    • Vertigo or imbalance, worsened by exertion or pressure changes
    • Tinnitus (ringing in the ears)
    • Ear fullness or pressure sensation
  • Potential Complications:
    • Recurrent meningitis, particularly in children with bony defects
    • Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks in more severe cases
  • Diagnosis:
    • Primarily clinical, based on patient history and symptoms
    • High-resolution CT of the temporal bone may show:
      • Pneumolabyrinth (air in the inner ear)
      • Ossicular disruption or fluid in the middle ear
      • Imaging may still appear normal despite symptoms
    • Exploratory surgery can be definitive in uncertain cases
  • Treatment:
    • Surgical repair (patching of the oval/round window) to seal the leak
    • Aimed at relieving vertigo and preventing further complications
  • Prognosis:
    • Vertigo often improves significantly after surgery
    • Hearing recovery is usually limited or incomplete

Explanation of other options:

Labyrinthitis (Option B): Typically presents after an infection (viral or bacterial) with acute vertigo and hearing loss. Lack of systemic signs and the history of prior surgery make this less likely.

Paget disease (Option C): A chronic bone disorder more common in the elderly; can affect hearing due to bony changes in the skull, but does not present with acute vertigo or symptom changes related to head position.

Vestibular schwannoma (Option D): Commonly presents with progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and imbalance, not typically influenced by head position, and less likely to follow ear surgery acutely.

Reference:

  1. https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/medicine-and-dentistry/perilymph-fistula#

questions.text: A patient complains of vertigo and is noted to have horizontal nystagmus on examination. The slow phase of the eye movement is directed toward the left. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's horizontal nystagmus with a slow phase toward the left indicates reduced vestibular input from the left labyrinth, pointing to a diagnosis of Left hypoactive labyrinth.

Hypoactive Labyrinth:

  • A hypoactive labyrinth refers to reduced function of the inner ear's balance organ, often due to trauma or pathology affecting the labyrinth or the vestibular portion of the 8th cranial nerve.
  • Mechanism of Imbalance:
    • When one side is under-functioning, the brain perceives unopposed input from the normal (opposite) side as continuous movement.
    • This asymmetry in input causes abnormal eye movements (nystagmus) as a compensatory response.
  • Nystagmus Pattern:
    • Slow phase: Eyes drift towards the side of the lesion (affected side).
    • Fast phase: Eyes jerk back toward the healthy side, which is the direction of the nystagmus.
  • Example:
    • In left-sided labyrinthine hypofunction, the eyes slowly move left (toward the lesion) and then rapidly correct right → Right-beating nystagmus.

Explanation of other options:

Posterior canal BPPV (Option A): Typically causes rotatory (torsional) nystagmus with an upward vertical component during positional testing (e.g., Dix-Hallpike), not pure horizontal nystagmus.

Superior canal BPPV (Option B): Usually results in downbeat torsional nystagmus, also triggered by positional changes, not a sustained horizontal nystagmus pattern.

Right hypoactive labyrinth (Option C): Would produce a slow phase to the right and fast phase (and named nystagmus) to the left, opposite of what's described here.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430797/#
  2. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441861/

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, failure to thrive, impaired hearing, and a high-arched palate. Otoscopic findings are unremarkable, and the tympanogram is shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
• A Type B tympanogram (flat tracing) indicates reduced tympanic membrane mobility, usually due to middle ear effusion, commonly seen in serous otitis media (SOM).
  • In a child with recurrent infections, hearing loss, and craniofacial risk factors like a high-arched palate, the most likely underlying cause is Eustachian tube dysfunction, often due to adenoid hypertrophy.
  • Therefore, the most appropriate management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

Tympanometry:

  • Used to assess the mobility (compliance) of the tympanic membrane and ossicular chain.
  • It measures how much sound is reflected back from the tympanic membrane while varying the pressure in the ear canal.
  • Also useful in assessing Eustachian tube function through pressure changes during swallowing.

Explanation of other options:

Myringotomy (Option A): While myringotomy alone can relieve middle ear effusion temporarily, without addressing the underlying cause (like adenoid hypertrophy), the effusion often recurs.

Grommet (Option B): Inserting a grommet alone helps ventilate the middle ear, but if the Eustachian tube remains blocked by enlarged adenoids, the problem is likely to persist or recur.

Myringotomy and grommet (Option C): This treats the effusion effectively but doesn't address the root cause, adenoid hypertrophy, which contributes to Eustachian tube dysfunction and recurrent otitis media.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with sudden-onset episodes of vertigo, sensorineural hearing loss, and a roaring tinnitus that lasts from several minutes to a few hours. These episodes are associated with nausea, vomiting, and signs of autonomic dysfunction. Further evaluation reveals increased endolymphatic pressure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and endolymphatic hypertension point towards a diagnosis of Meniere's disease.

Meniere's Disease:

  • A disorder of the inner ear caused by excessive accumulation of endolymph, affecting both hearing and balance.
  • Typical Age Group: Most commonly affects individuals between 35 and 60 years of age.
  • Gender Predilection: Slightly more common in males.

Explanation of other options:

Presbycusis (Option B): This is a progressive, bilateral age-related hearing loss affecting high frequencies and does not cause vertigo or episodic tinnitus.

Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (Option C): BPPV causes brief episodes of vertigo triggered by positional changes of the head. It is not associated with hearing loss or tinnitus.

Acoustic neuroma (Option D): A slow-growing tumor of the vestibulocochlear nerve, it presents with gradual unilateral SNHL and persistent, not episodic, symptoms. Vertigo is usually less prominent and constant.

questions.text: A South Indian male farmer presents to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of a reddish, fleshy mass protruding from his nose, as shown below. He reports occasional blood-stained nasal discharge and nasal obstruction. A biopsy was taken, and the corresponding histopathological image is also shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of exposure, nasal bleeding, and presence of a reddish polypoidal mass, combined with histology showing characteristic sporangia with multiple endospores, points toward rhinosporidiosis, a chronic infection caused by Rhinosporidiumseeberi.

Rhinosporidiosis:

  • A chronic granulomatous infection caused by Rhinosporidiumseeberi, an aquatic protozoan parasite.
  • Transmission:
    • Acquired through exposure to stagnant water, often contaminated with organic waste (e.g., cow dung).
    • Entry through traumatized nasal mucosa is common.
  • Life Cycle Stages:
    • Begins with a trophocyte stage.
    • Progresses to sporangium formation.
    • Ends with endospore release, which infects nearby tissues.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Intermittent nasal bleeding (epistaxis).
    • Unilateral nasal blockage or discharge.
    • Soft, polyp-like reddish mass in the nasal cavity.
    • Lesion often has a granular surface with visible white dots (mature sporangia).
    • Bleeds readily upon manipulation due to high vascularity.

Explanation of other options:

Rhinoscleroma (Option B): Caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, presents with progressive nasal obstruction and woody nasal masses. Histology shows Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies, not sporangia.

Rhinophyma (Option C): Seen as a bulbous nasal deformity due to sebaceous gland overgrowth, usually in the setting of rosacea, not associated with nasal masses or bleeding.

Nasal polyp (Option D): Benign, soft, pale or grayish translucent outgrowths often associated with chronic rhinosinusitis and allergy. They are non-vascular and don't typically bleed or show sporangia on biopsy.

choices.text: Closed reduction after edema subsides in 20 days
Closed reduction after 7-14 days, once swelling subsides

questions.text: A young boy presents to the ENT outpatient department after a fall during play. He complains of nasal deviation but has no breathing difficulty or nasal discharge. On clinical examination, the nasal septum appears to be midline with no signs of septal hematoma. A CT scan of the nasal bones is performed, as shown below. What should be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has a nasal fracture with an intact septum, and the CT shows no complex displacement. In such cases, closed reduction is the treatment of choice, typically performed after swelling reduces naturally in about 7-14 days to allow better anatomical alignment.

Nasal Fracture Management (Without Septal Involvement):

  • Initial Approach: Wait for 10-14 days post-trauma to allow swelling (edema) to subside before attempting reduction.
  • Preferred Treatment: Closed reduction is the treatment of choice for isolated nasal bone fractures without septal deviation.
  • Early reduction while swelling persists may hinder accurate alignment and increase the risk of incomplete or incorrect reduction.
  • Septo-rhinoplasty is reserved for cases with significant septal deformity or complex fractures.
  • Open reduction is used only when closed methods fail or the fracture is severely displaced or comminuted.

Explanation of other options:

Septo-rhinoplasty (Option A): Reserved for cases with septal deviation or major cosmetic deformity requiring surgical reconstruction, unnecessary in this simple fracture.

Open reduction (Option B): More invasive and typically used for comminuted or complex fractures not suitable for closed reduction.

Closed reduction after edema subsides in 20 days (Option C): Delaying for 20 days risks ossification and poor outcomes; timely intervention within 2 weeks is ideal.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents with a 7-month history of dysphagia, halitosis, and occasional regurgitation of undigested food. He also reports episodes of chronic cough, especially after meals. A barium swallow study is performed, and the radiograph is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical and radiological findings?
questions.solution:
The patient's chronic dysphagia and halitosis, along with imaging showing a posterior pouch at the pharyngoesophageal junction, point toward Zenker's diverticulum.

Zenker's Diverticulum:

  • A false diverticulum that protrudes posteriorly above the cricopharyngeal sphincter.
  • Arises through Killian's dehiscence, a weak area between oblique and horizontal fibers of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor.
  • Caused by uncoordinated swallowing leading to increased pressure and mucosal herniation.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Early stages: Symptoms of pharyngeal dysphagia due to impaired bolus transit.
    • Advanced cases:
      • Halitosis (due to retained food in the pouch)
      • Regurgitation of undigested food
      • Chronic cough and risk of aspiration
      • Dysphagia may worsen over time
      • The pouch may extend downward into the upper mediastinum
  • Diagnostic Methods:
    • Barium swallow (Esophagogram): Best initial test showing a posterior outpouching
    • Esophageal manometry: Evaluates upper esophageal sphincter function
    • Endoscopy: Caution advised, risk of perforating the diverticulum
    • MRI/CT: Occasionally used if mass effect or complications are suspected
  • Management:
    • Surgical options:
      • Diverticulectomy with cricopharyngeal myotomy
      • Diverticulopexy/suspension: Fixing the pouch without resection; reduces leak risk
    • Minimally invasive techniques:
      • Endoscopic stapling using a transoral linear stapler, preferred in many centers for small to moderate pouches

Explanation of other options:

Plummer-Vinson syndrome (Option B): Characterized by dysphagia, iron deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs, usually without halitosis or regurgitation of undigested food.

Esophageal malignancy (Option C): Often presents with rapidly progressive dysphagia (first solids, then liquids) and weight loss, and does not produce a posterior outpouching on barium swallow.

Achalasia cardia (Option D): Presents with dysphagia to both solids and liquids, with barium swallow showing a "bird-beak" narrowing at the lower esophageal sphincter, not a cervical pouch.

Reference: Zenker Diverticulum

questions.text: A 45-year-old female undergoes total thyroidectomy for a large multinodular goiter. In the postoperative period, she develops stridor and difficulty breathing. Laryngoscopic examination reveals that both vocal cords are immobile and positioned in the midline. Which of the following is the most likely nerve injury responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution: This patient presents with acute airway compromise following thyroid surgery, and laryngoscopy shows immobile vocal cords in the midline, a hallmark of bilateral complete RLN palsy. In this condition, both vocal cords are paralyzed in a median or paramedian position, severely narrowing the glottic airway and leading to stridor and respiratory distress, making it a life-threatening emergency. Immediate management often requires tracheostomy to secure the airway.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with severe bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and no improvement with hearing aids. Audiological assessment confirms that the auditory nerve is intact. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The child has severe sensorineural hearing loss with no benefit from hearing aids but an intact auditory nerve, which makes cochlear implantation the most appropriate next step to restore hearing by directly stimulating the nerve.

Cochlear Implant:

  • Cochlear implants are surgically implanted electronic devices used to restore hearing in individuals with severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL).
  • They bypass damaged hair cells in the cochlea and directly stimulate the auditory nerve, allowing sound perception.
  • Indications:
    • Bilateral severe SNHL (70-90 dB)
    • Bilateral profound SNHL (>90 dB)
    • Pre-lingual deafness: Congenital hearing loss before speech development
    • Post-lingual deafness: Hearing loss occurring after speech has been acquired
  • Contraindications:
    • Cochlear aplasia
    • Eighth nerve abnormalities (e.g., nerve aplasia or retrocochlear lesions)
    • Central auditory pathway disorders
    • Michel aplasia (complete absence of inner ear structures, including the cochlea)
  • Device Components:
    • External Components
      • Microphone: Picks up sound from the environment
      • Speech processor: Converts sound into digital signals
      • Transmitting coil: Sends signals through the skin to the implanted receiver
    • Internal Components
      • Receiver/stimulator: Converts digital signals into electrical impulses
      • Electrode array: Placed inside the cochlea to deliver impulses directly to the auditory nerve

Explanation of other options:

Hearing Aids (Option A): These are ineffective in cases of severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss, as they only amplify sound and require some residual cochlear function.

BAHA (Bone Anchored Hearing Aid) (Option B): Primarily used for conductive or mixed hearing loss and not suitable when the cochlea is non-functional, as in profound SNHL.

Auditory Brainstem Implant (Option D): Indicated only when the auditory nerve is absent or non-functional; not preferred here since the child has an intact auditory nerve, making cochlear implant a better choice.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK544280/

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the clinic with persistent noisy breathing since birth. The parents report that the stridor becomes worse when the baby is lying down or feeding. There is no history of fever, cough, or cyanosis. On examination, inspiratory stridor is noted. A flexible laryngoscopic image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of inspiratory stridor in a child, along with an omega-shaped epiglottis on laryngoscopy, points towards the diagnosis of laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia:

  • Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of congenital stridor in infants.
  • Etiology: Caused by congenital floppiness of the laryngeal cartilage, particularly involving the epiglottis and arytenoids.
  • Symptoms:
    • Inspiratory stridor that worsens when the infant is supine, feeding, or crying.
    • Typically absent during sleep.
  • Onset and Course:
    • Begins at birth or within the first few weeks of life.
    • Peaks around 4-8 months.
    • Usually resolves spontaneously by 12-24 months.
  • Laryngoscopic Findings:
    • Omega-shaped epiglottis.
    • Redundant arytenoid mucosa that prolapses during inspiration.
  • Diagnosis: Confirmed via flexible laryngoscopy.
  • Management:
    • Mild cases: Observation and reassurance.
    • Severe cases (feeding difficulty, apnea, failure to thrive): Supraglottoplasty.

Explanation of other options:

Vocal cord paralysis (Option A): Typically causes biphasic stridor (heard during both inspiration and expiration) and a weak or breathy cry, unlike the purely inspiratory stridor of laryngomalacia.

Subglottic stenosis (Option B): Produces biphasic stridor and may present after a history of intubation, which is not mentioned here.

Laryngeal papilloma (Option C): Commonly causes progressive hoarseness and voice changes; stridor appears later and is usually expiratory or biphasic, not primarily inspiratory.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with nasal swelling and difficulty breathing after falling from a bed. On examination, smooth, rounded, soft, and fluctuant swellings are observed on both sides of the septum through both nostrils. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
The child's history of trauma, bilateral nasal obstruction, and examination findings of soft, fluctuant swellings on either side of the septum are classic for a septal hematoma. Immediate incision and drainage are crucial to prevent serious complications such as septal abscess, cartilage necrosis, and saddle nose deformity.

Septal Hematoma:


  • Results from blood collecting between the septal cartilage and mucoperichondrium.
  • Etiology:
    • Trauma to the nose (most common cause).
    • Following nasal or septal surgical procedures.
    • It can occur spontaneously in patients with coagulopathies.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Bilateral nasal blockage is the most common presenting symptom.
    • Headache or a sensation of pressure over the nasal bridge.
    • Fluctuant, smooth swelling seen in one or both nasal cavities on anterior rhinoscopy.
  • Treatment:
    • Small hematomas: Managed by needle aspiration using a sterile wide-bore needle.
    • Large hematomas: Require incision and drainage through a small mucosal cut parallel to the nasal floor; a part of the mucosa may be excised to facilitate drainage.
    • Bilateral nasal packing is used to prevent reaccumulation.
    • Systemic antibiotics are prescribed to prevent infection or abscess formation.
  • Complications (if untreated):
    • Fibrosis and septal thickening.
    • Septal abscess, which may result in:
      • Cartilage necrosis
      • Saddle nose deformity (collapse of nasal dorsum)

Explanation of other options:

Systemic antibiotics (Option A): Antibiotics alone do not treat the underlying hematoma; they may prevent infection, but surgical drainage is essential to relieve pressure and avoid cartilage necrosis.

High-resolution computerized tomography (Option C): CT is not necessary for diagnosing a septal hematoma, which is a clinical diagnosis; it's only indicated if there's suspicion of complex nasal fractures.

Submucosal resection (Option D): This is a corrective surgery for chronic septal deviations and has no role in acute trauma or hematoma management, which requires simple drainage.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with severe, persistent ear pain and discharge that has not responded to antibiotics. On otoscopic examination, there is granulation tissue in the external auditory canal, and facial nerve paralysis is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's symptoms of intense, unrelenting otalgia, chronic otorrhea, granulation tissue, and facial nerve involvement, particularly in a diabetic individual, are characteristic of malignant otitis externa (MOE).

Malignant (Necrotizing) Otitis Externa:


  • A severe form of otitis externa caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Typically seen in elderly diabetics or immunocompromised individuals.
  • Presents with intense ear pain, granulation tissue in the external auditory canal, and possible facial nerve palsy.
  • It can spread to the skull base and cause multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • Pathogenesis & Spread:
    • Initial symptoms mimic diffuse otitis externa but with more severe pain.
    • Granulation tissue within the ear canal indicates advancing disease.
    • Infection can extend:
      • Anteriorly to the temporomandibular joint.
      • Posteriorly to the mastoid.
      • Medially to the middle ear and the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  • Diagnostic Workup:
    • Based on clinical suspicion, especially in elderly diabetics with persistent otalgia.
    • CT/MRI: Useful for assessing bone destruction and soft tissue extension.
    • Gallium-67 scan: Sensitive for active infection and useful for monitoring response.
    • Technetium-99 scan: Good for detecting osteomyelitis but stays positive long after recovery, so less useful for follow-up.
  • Treatment:
    • Glycemic control is essential in diabetic patients.
    • Aural toilet: Regular cleaning to remove discharge and granulation tissue.
    • Antibiotics:
      • IV options: Gentamicin + Ticarcillin (monitor for oto-/nephrotoxicity).
      • Alternatives: Ceftriaxone or Ceftazidime (3rd gen cephalosporins) + aminoglycoside.
      • Oral: High-dose Ciprofloxacin (750 mg) ± Rifampin.
    • Treatment duration: Typically 6-8 weeks or longer.
    • Modify antibiotics based on culture and sensitivity.
    • Surgery is rarely needed due to effective long-term antibiotic therapy.

Explanation of other options:

Otomycosis (Option A): Fungal infection of the external ear, usually presenting with itching, mild pain, and thick white or black debris. It does not cause granulation tissue, facial nerve paralysis, or severe pain, which are hallmark signs of malignant otitis externa.

Serous otitis media (Option B): This condition involves non-infected fluid accumulation in the middle ear, often secondary to Eustachian tube dysfunction. It typically presents with hearing loss and a retracted tympanic membrane, but not ear discharge, granulation tissue, or nerve involvement.

Eczematous otitis externa (Option D): This is a superficial skin condition of the external auditory canal that causes itching, redness, scaling, and sometimes mild pain. It does not involve deep tissue infection, granulation tissue, or cranial nerve palsy, which are features of malignant otitis externa.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic woman who was treated with steroids and remdesivir for COVID-19 now presents with foul-smelling black nasal discharge. On examination, a black necrotic mass is seen in the nasal cavity with destruction of the septum and hard palate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of black necrotic nasal discharge, septal and palatal erosion in a diabetic post-COVID patient strongly suggests mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis:

  • Aggressive fungal infection mainly affecting the nasal cavity and sinuses.
  • Can rapidly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain.
  • Causes arterial invasion, leading to endothelial damage, thrombosis, and extensive tissue necrosis.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Black necrotic tissue is seen in the nasal cavity.
    • Destruction of the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates.
    • Black turbinate sign on contrast-enhanced MRI is a characteristic imaging finding.
  • Predisposing Factors
    • Uncontrolled diabetes, especially with diabetic ketoacidosis.
    • Use of steroids, notably in COVID-19
    • Immunosuppressed states
  • Diagnosis:
    • Nasal Endoscopy: Initially pale mucosa; progresses to black crusting and necrosis.
    • Biopsy:
      • Multiple site samples recommended.
      • KOH mount helps visualize fungal hyphae (broad, aseptate, right-angled branching).
    • Imaging Modalities:
      • CT Scan: Helps detect sinus involvement and bony erosion.
      • CECT: Provides better visualization of soft tissue involvement.
      • MRI: Essential for evaluating orbital and intracranial spread.
  • Management
    • Antifungal Therapy:
      • Conventional Amphotericin B: 0.6-1 mg/kg/day IV.
      • Liposomal Amphotericin B: 5 mg/kg/day (preferred due to lower toxicity).
    • Surgical Treatment:
      • Endoscopic removal of necrotic tissue.
      • In advanced cases:
        • Partial/total maxillectomy.
        • Orbital exenteration if the orbit is extensively involved.

Explanation of other options:

Aspergillosis (Option A): Typically causes chronic sinusitis or allergic fungal sinusitis and does not usually lead to rapid tissue necrosis or black eschar; less aggressive than mucormycosis.

Foreign body (Option C): May cause foul-smelling discharge, especially in children, but rarely leads to extensive necrosis or erosion of the nasal septum and palate.

Rhinosporidiosis (Option D): Presents with reddish, polypoidal masses containing white dots (sporangia), not black necrotic tissue; it's chronic and non-invasive, unlike the rapidly destructive pattern of mucormycosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female school teacher presents with persistent hoarseness and vocal fatigue for the past 3 months. She reports increased throat discomfort after prolonged speaking. Laryngoscopic appearance is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's profession as a teacher involves frequent voice use, and the laryngoscopic finding of bilateral lesions at the midpoint of the vocal cords is characteristic of vocal nodules caused by chronic vocal strain.


Explanation of other options:

Vocal cysts (Option B): Cysts are subepithelial, typically unilateral, and do not commonly occur in professional voice users; they usually cause more persistent hoarseness without the classic midpoint bilateral lesions.

Reinke's oedema (Option D): This condition involves diffuse swelling of the vocal folds due to fluid accumulation (often from smoking), and presents with a deeper, gravelly voice, less typical in younger or non-smoking teachers with focal lesions.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant is admitted to the ICU with a history of recurrent ear and sinus infections, primarily caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Laboratory evaluation reveals very low levels of all major immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, IgM, and IgE) and an absence of circulating B cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with recurrent bacterial infections, markedly low immunoglobulin levels, and absent B cells points toward a diagnosis of Bruton syndrome (X-linked agammaglobulinemia).

Bruton Syndrome (X-linked Agammaglobulinemia):

  • Cause: Mutation in the BTK gene (Bruton tyrosine kinase), leading to defective B-cell maturation.
  • Immunological Defect:
    • Marked reduction or absence of mature B cells in the peripheral blood.
    • Plasma cells (antibody-producing cells) are absent.
    • Serum levels of all immunoglobulin classes (IgG, IgA, IgM, IgE) are significantly reduced.
  • Infection Susceptibility:
    • Increased risk of recurrent bacterial infections, particularly by encapsulated organisms like:
      • Staphylococcus aureus
      • Streptococcus pneumoniae
      • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Common Clinical Presentations:
    • Repeated sinus infections, otitis media, and lower respiratory tract infections.
    • Symptoms typically begin at around 6 months of age, after maternal IgG protection fades.
  • Laboratory Findings:
    • Low or absent immunoglobulins in serum.
    • Absent B cells on flow cytometry.

Explanation of other options:

Ataxia Telangiectasia (Option A): Although it may show IgA deficiency, it typically presents with cerebellar ataxia and telangiectasias, and does not show complete absence of B cells or pan-hypogammaglobulinemia.

Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) (Option B): This involves defective neutrophil oxidative burst, leading to recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, but immunoglobulin levels and B cell numbers are usually normal.

DiGeorge Syndrome (Option D): Characterized by thymic aplasia and T-cell deficiency, leading to viral and fungal infections, not the recurrent bacterial infections or low B cells seen in Bruton syndrome.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448170/
